Bringing Hong Kong bomb-plot suspects to book using international anti-terrorism laws is not a political move but a necessary preventive measure to curb the growing threat of local extremism, the city’s security minister has said. ï¼ˆä¿å®‰å±€é•·ç¨±ï¼Œä»¥åœ‹éš›åææ³•å°‡é¦™æ¸¯ç‚¸å½ˆæ¡ˆç–‘çŠ¯ç¹©ä¹‹æ–¼æ³•ä¸¦éæ”¿æ²»æ“ä½œï¼Œä¹ƒæ˜¯ç‚ºåˆ¶æ­¢æœ¬åœ°æ¥µç«¯ä¸»ç¾©çš„å¿…è¦é é˜²æªæ–½ã€‚ï¼‰

As revealed earlier by the Post, police are mulling the use of a UN ordinance against a group suspected of making explosives for use in the city. And John Lee Ka-chiu said the legislation would be more effective than local laws at cutting off financial and other support for home-grown terrorism.

“[The threat] is developing ... If we want to nip it in the bud, [we should] ensure that they do not get any oxygen at all,” Lee said in an exclusive interview.

He blamed “the habitual violence” of recent anti-government protests for giving rise to local terrorism, adding that if the public did not join hands to stifle its growth, he could not rule out the possibility of raising the city’s current threat level from “moderate” to “high”.

Police have confiscated at least five guns and cracked more than 10 bomb cases since the anti-government protests began in June.

The seized weapons, including 2kg of the powerful explosive TATP and an AR-15 rifle, are commonly used in terror attacks overseas. This prompted officials to study the possibility of building terrorist cases by using the city’s United Nations (Anti-Terrorism Measures) Ordinance.

Both the UN legislation – brought in after the attacks of September 11, 2001 – and the local Crimes Ordinance carry a maximum term of life imprisonment for convicted bomb makers. ï¼ˆè¯åˆåœ‹æ³•ä¾‹-æ–¼911å¾Œå¼•å…¥-åŠæœ¬åœ°åˆ‘äº‹æ¢å°±è¢«å®šç½ªç‚¸å½ˆåˆ¶é€ è€…å‡æœ€é«˜èƒ½åˆ¤è™•çµ‚èº«ç›£ç¦ã€‚ï¼‰But Lee said the former empowered the government to freeze suspected terrorists’ property, thereby cutting off their financing and halting their recruitment. ï¼ˆä½†æè£œå……ï¼Œå‰è€…èƒ½æˆæ¬Šæ”¿åºœå‡çµææ€–åˆ†å­ç–‘çŠ¯è²¡ç”¢ï¼Œä»¥çµ‚æ–·è²¡æ”¿è³‡åŠ©åŠåœæ­¢æ‹›å‹Ÿã€‚ï¼‰ï¼»è©•ï¼šå§ä¿‚ä½ æ¯”äººå‘Šï¼Œä½ æˆ–ä½ å®¶äººè³‡ç”¢æœ‰å¯èƒ½è¢«å‡çµï¼Œä½¢åœ°è¦è¨“è¡—ï¼Œå¤§å®¶åšå‰ä¸‰æ€ï¼½

“You cut off the oxygen and disallow the group to grow. These are all preventive measures which other ordinances may not so effectively allow,” he said.

He added that resorting to such drastic measures would have “an education and announcement effect”, letting the public know the gravity of the situation.
“Call a spade a spade, in other words. If a heinous act is actually a terrorist act, then using the appropriate law gives that message and [places things in] the right perspective.”

Under the UN ordinance, Hong Kong’s chief executive can apply to the Court of First Instance for an order to designate a suspect as a terrorist or terrorist associate. (æ ¹æ“šè¯åˆåœ‹æ¢ä¾‹ï¼Œé¦™æ¸¯è¡Œæ”¿é•·å®˜å¯å‘åŸè¨Ÿåº­ç”³è«‹å°‡æŸç–‘çŠ¯ç•Œå®šç‚ºææ€–åˆ†å­ï¼‰Lee brushed off the suggestion that invoking the UN law could serve a political rather than a security purpose, adding that the authorities only took cases to court based on evidence.


On the possibility of raising the local threat level, Lee said: “I don’t rule out any possibility. But at the moment, I think we are at a stage where we see a developing trend. But we are also at a stage where we can stop it. I remain confident that our law enforcement agencies are on top of it.”

When dealing with the threat alerts, the minister said, the government must look at how organised, well financed and sophisticated the enemies are, as well as city agencies’ ability to eliminate their threat.

He said that, should the high threat level come in, the city would need to step up security, including sealing off high-risk locations, maintaining high-profile patrols, and conducting bag searches and security checks on people in public.

Until recently, officials seldom discussed local terrorism, the minister blaming the violence of 2019’s protests for inuring people to the problem, saying that everyone should condemn the radical actions.

Appealing for public support, he said: “It’s important that we collectively cut it. So anybody who stands in the [way of a] police operation when they take action against these potential terrorists, it is a serious matter. They have to be dealt with as well because these are the people who are providing oxygen to the terrorists.”
He added that the internet also allowed like-minded dissidents to get together and form groups.

“Then they socialise, discuss among themselves, reinforce and echo each other, so that this extreme idea gets amplified and aggravated. The self-reinforcement gets to such a stage that then they become radicalised,” he said.

Lee also believed the radicals were trained. ï¼ˆæç›¸ä¿¡æ¥µç«¯åˆ†å­æ›¾å—è¨“ç·´ã€‚ï¼‰“I think if you look at the organisation of the activities, the resources that they get and the division of labour – that is so clear among some of the activities – and the strategy and plan ... this isn’t something that could be done by the men in the street, right? So obviously, they have been [receiving] training,” he said.

Police seized more than two tonnes of explosives and chemicals in early March, arresting at least 17 people. Detectives believed those held were linked to three bomb plots in January and February, when an explosive device went off at a public hospital, along with another on a train at Lo Wu station, while another was found at Shenzhen Bay border control point. Some people claimed responsibility on a social media platform before and after the plots, saying they intended to pressure the government into closing the city’s border with mainland China in response to the spread of the deadly coronavirus.

In 2018, the Security Bureau set up the Inter-departmental Counter Terrorism Unit (ICTU), composed of officers from six disciplined services – police, immigration, customs, correctional services, the fire service and the government flying service. As political unrest has intensified, Lee said, the unit has focused more on reviewing strategy and advising him on the right counterterror measures. The team also needs to prevent local extremists from connecting with others overseas, he said.

Without going into details, Lee added that staff across the departments collect and share intelligence, enabling the city to neutralise groups before they can act.
“There are a lot of behind-the-scenes heroes who sacrifice their days and nights, who may lose their sleep while other people are enjoying their lives,” he said.
“When eventually they have neutralised vicious gangs and terrorist radicals, they are the people who then go to sleep and get back to their normal day to work. There are so many unsung heroes and I thank them all.”
